sections.1_story_intuition: Books and their authors are a frequent topic in competitive exams. Knowing famous books, their writers, and recent award-winning works helps in scoring well in the GK section. This section covers important books, Indian and international authors, and exam-relevant facts.
2_key_definitions: Author: A person who writes books or literary works.
Literature: Written works, especially those considered of superior or lasting artistic merit.
Autobiography: A book written by a person about their own life.
Biography: A book written about someone else's life.
Fiction: Literature created from the imagination.
Non-fiction: Literature based on facts and real events.
Poetry: Literary work in verse form.
Drama: A play for theatre, radio, or television.
Award: Recognition given for achievement in literature.

4_micro_notes: 'Wings of Fire' is APJ Abdul Kalam's autobiography.
'To Kill a Mockingbird' is by Harper Lee.

'My Experiments with Truth' is Gandhi's autobiography.

7_traps_confusing_points: Mixing up Booker and Nobel Prize winners.
Assuming all famous books are novels.
Mixing up Indian and foreign authors.
Assuming all award-winning books are in English.
Confusing 'The Guide' (R.K. Narayan) with 'The God of Small Things' (Arundhati Roy).
Mixing up 'Wings of Fire' and 'My Experiments with Truth'.
Assuming all books listed are fiction.
Confusing 'The Alchemist' author (Paulo Coelho) with 'The Monk Who Sold His Ferrari' (Robin Sharma).

8_case_study_context.title: Nobel Prize for Gitanjali
8_case_study_context.explanation: Rabindranath Tagore was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1913 for his collection of poems 'Gitanjali'. This was the first Nobel Prize awarded to an Asian, making it a historic achievement in world literature.
